Problem:
Consider a linear time-invariant system governed by the differential equation \(\\dot{x} = Kx\), where K is a constant matrix. Investigate the system's behavior under the transformation \( g(x) = Q^{-1}x \) over time t, where Q is a constant and invertible matrix.

If \( g(x) \) is applied to a vector \( x_0 \) at t = 0, and then allowed to evolve under \(\\dot{x} = Kx\) without further intervention, will \( x(t) \) at t = T be the same as if \( x_0 \) was directly evolved to t = T under \(\\dot{x} = Kx\)?
Explanation: Applying \( g(x) \) to \( x_0 \) at t = 0 alters the initial condition to \( x_0' = Q^{-1}x_0 \). The system evolves from \( x_0' \) under \(\\dot{x} = Kx\), and due to this changed initial condition, \( x(t) \) at t = T will generally not match the state had \( x_0 \) been evolved with no transformation.
